newsitem.title: BELGIUM: And the band played on for Belgian shares.
newsitem.headline: And the band played on for Belgian shares.

text.p: Belgium's Bel-20 index of leading shares, basking again in its glory after notching up another percent on Thursday, will continue to stroll on the upward trail, dealers and analysts said.

"The climat remains favourable. The dollar has jumped with such a force that we don't expect it to fall back like that. We also expect interest rates to stay low," said Stefan Casteleyn at Antwerp brokerage Corluy & Co.
The Bel-20 closed 22.42 points higher at 2,193.53 after earlier touching a new record high of 2,195.48. A high 4.9 billion francs worth of Belgian shares were traded.
Casteleyn noted that at the end of 1996 he had set a 12-month target for the Bel-20 of 2,300 points, which at the time made him by far the most optimistic analyst.
"Now it might just have been too conservative," he said.
Dealers said that investors were buying "just anything". "We call them loose hands, they will also be the first ones to sell once the market turns," one said.
Casteleyn said that holdings such as GBL and smaller stocks such as holdings Mosane and Belcofi were still a buy at current levels.
GBL, which closed 50 francs higher at 5,200, was still quoted 25 percent lower at 4,085 francs just two months ago.

"And yet it's still attractive," Castelyn said. He said that holdings had -- and still have -- a considerable discount in relation to their intrinsic value and had originally been 30 percent in some cases.
Traders said that both institutionals and retail investors were still on a buying spree.
"Many of the retail investors decide to invest in shares once their bonds mature and the only other option is to invest at much lower rates," Casteleyn said.

Diversified shipping group CMB was the day's leading gainer with a 3.6 percent leap to 2,720 francs, which traders put down to the dollar effect and the fact it had taken it longer than other shares to start its rise.
Insurer Fortis AG came second with a 2.7 percent gain to 6,410 but one trader referred to a recent positive assessment which said the share had the potential to soar to 7,000.
